location: England, Dorset, Dorchester, Maiden Castle Road
description: Two temple structures located in Maiden Castle hillfort, the earlier (1) is circular, and the later square temple (2), Lewis suggests to have been constructed in the early 3rd CE and have gone out of use in the early or mid 5th CE. Maiden Castle shows earlier use as a possible location for parts of the burial process, which may have some connection to the later temples.
bibliography: Booth, Thomas J., and Richard Madgwick. “New Evidence for Diverse Secondary Burial Practices in Iron Age Britain: A Histological Case Study.” Journal of Archaeological Science 67 (2016): 14–24. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jas.2016.01.010.
Martyn, Blick, Brindle, and et al. “Maiden Castle (Dorset).” The Rural Settlement of Roman Britain: an online resource, 2015. https://doi.org/10.5284/1030449.

Russell, Miles. “Mythmakers of Maiden Castle: Breaking the Siege Mentality of an Iron Age Hillfort.” Oxford Journal of Archaeology 38, no. 3 (2019). https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/ojoa.12172.
Sharples. “Maiden Castle: Excavations and Field Survey 1985-6 (1991).” Nglish Heritage Archaeological Report no. 19 (1991).
Toynbee, J. M. C. In Art in Roman Britain. 40, 1909.
Wheeler, R. E. M. Maiden Castle, 1943.
